text:
Tory GP Teck Khong defects to UKIP to contest Harborough General Election seat By danjmartin | Posted: May 09, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Teck Khong has defected from the Tories to UKIP to fight the Harbourough seat in the General Election Tory GP Teck Khong defects to UKIP to contest Harborough General Election seat X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Teck Khong has defected from the Tories to UKIP to fight the Harbourough seat in the General Election Comments (0) 
UKIP have also announced their Harborough General Election candidate Dr Teck Khong who has defected from the Tory party. 
The Oadby and Wigston borough councillor is a GP who lives in Nottinghamshire and works for a practice in Eyres Monsell, Leicester. 
He has recently quit the Conservatives having previously been removed from a 1,500-strong list of potential candidates by party bosses. 
The father-of-three said: "As a doctor, I am humbled and privileged to care for the entire spectrum of our society in a variety of appointments. 
General Election 2017: Click HERE for everything you need to know 
"I was born in British Malaya, a paragon of racial harmony, and my upbringing has given me an enduring sense of dedication and loyalty to Britain and the Commonwealth. I look forward to serving our country in Parliament, particularly in health and social care." 
Dr Khong has previously served on the governing body of NHS Leicester City Clinical Commissioning Group, with lead roles in Safeguarding Adults, Safeguarding Children, Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS), Family, Young People & Children (FYPC) and the Serious Incidents Review Panel. 
UKIP leader Paul Nuttall said. "I'm delighted to welcome Dr Khong to the party. He has a wealth of experience both in healthcare and in politics and will be a great asset. 
"That Teck has chosen to support UKIP at this time shows clearly that the scales are beginning to fall from the eyes of Tories about the vacuum where a serious Brexit policy lies in Theresa May's Conservative Party." 
A Tory party source told the Mercury: "Teck is desperate to become an MP and doesn't seem to mind which party he will represent. 
"I rather think joining UKIP now moves him away from that ambition not closer to it."
